Description: Brown clay oil lamp with dark brown staining and a relief design on its body. There is a hole in the center of the body, surrounded by a floral design. The design is surrounded by a structure with a dome roof. The rest of the surface of the top of the lamp is covered in dark brown stains. There is a nozzle at the narrow end of the lamp, which is covered in brown stains, and some chips. The bottom of the lamp is mostly dark brown, and has a flat base.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Spurlock Museum, University of Illinois. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Registered as circa '50BC'. Parallel from Naukratis, but with simpler design (Boston RES.86.132). Rough parallels for this rare form are in the British Museum (Bailey Q591, Q565), but with different decoration, and should be dated to the late 1st century BC and the1st century AD, but could be later.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.059) (Phase 3)
